AC Milan could make a summer move for star Crystal Palace midfielder Luka Milivojevic, according to the latest reports.
The Rossoneri look set to say goodbye to Riccardo Montolivo, Jose Mauri and Andrea Bertolacci at the end of the season on free transfers.
In addition, there are still doubts about the redemption of Tiemoué Bakayoko, meaning that Leonardo will definitely be shopping around for potential midfield targets.
Advertisement
According to Calciomercato.it, a new name is being considered to reinforce the middle of the park in Serbian enforcer Milivojevic, who has scored 10 goals in 35 appearances for Palace this season.
With a contract expiring at the end of next season, it is possible that the former Olympiacos and Anderlecht man could leave the south London club for a reduced fee.

Milan fly out for Everton?
Milan sporting director Leonardo has reportedly flown to Brazil for talks with Gremio over a deal for winger Everton Soares.

According to Fox Sports Brasil, Leonardo will use the trip to drive down Gremio’s asking price of €80m – which is Everton’s release clause.

The broadcaster explains the Brazilian side are prepared to sell the 23-year-old but only once their participation in the Copa Libertadores is over.

Leonardo also played a key role in bringing Lucas Paqueta to San Siro earlier in the season.

Gattuso: Milan are my future
Gennaro Gattuso has insisted that his future lies with Milan. “I still have two years left on my contract…”

Two defeats and a draw have damaged Milan’s hopes of returning to the Champions League next season, and their preparations for Saturday’s Serie A showdown with Juventus have been hit by injuries to Gianluigi Donnarumma and Lucas Paqueta.

“We’ve struggled since the derby. We have to understand why,” Gattuso said at a Press conference.

“I hear about my relationship with Leonardo and Maldini, but there’s absolutely nothing [wrong].

“The conversations we’ve had are normal between Coaches and directors. The jam is on the field, because we’ve stopped shining. The rest is all talk.

“The match against Juve falls into place for us like a glove. A positive result would undoubtedly give us more morale.

“We were unlucky against Udinese. Gigio will be out for a week, while the Brazilian will be out for longer, between three weeks and a month.

“Romagnoli had a fever but will be there. Kessie and Calhanoglu are doing well and Conti will be back for our next game.

“History says we do better when we suffer, but our problems must be cleared quickly. Goals like the one against Udinese would never have happened a month ago.

“Whoever says we haven’t been playing well, I can live with that.”

The latest reports link the Coach with Roma, where he would reunite with former Italy teammate Francesco Totti...

“I still have two years left on my contract, my future is at Milan,” he asserted.

“I played with Allegri at Perugia, we won a League together. He’s the opposite of how I live this job.

“I remember never seeing him angry. Juve have already practically won the Scudetto, but the Bianconeri never give up.

“They’re a very good team, so we’ll need a great performance to bring home the points.”

Qatar eyes on Roma & Milan?
The Qatari government is reportedly considering investment in Roma or Milan as it looks to expand its portfolio in football.

According to Milano Finanza, Qatar – which already owns Paris Saint-Germain through the Qatar Investment Authority - is ‘following the two clubs closely’.

The website explains James Pallotta could sell up if the Stadio della Roma project continues to stagnate, with the Giallorossi already sponsored by Qatar Airways.

However, the lukewarm response to Qatari involvement at the Olimpico would have kept Milan ‘under consideration’.

Calcio e Finanza writes that while Elliott Management has guaranteed investment in the Rossoneri, it could leave the club in Qatari hands once the club’s accounts have been settled and plans for a new stadium are approved.

The Qatar Investment Authority group – who own PSG – are reportedly considering the idea of purchasing AC Milan or AS Roma.
Milan currently are owned by American firm Elliot Management who have a reputation as a “vulture fund”. This is described as buying low value or at risk assets then selling for a profit.

As expected, Elliott would like to flip the value of the club then sell to the highest bidder, in this case a very competent ownership group in Qatar Investment Authority – Milano Finanza claims.

Elliot however are not in a position to sell the club yet as they have only been at the helm for roughly one year. They have plans to first and foremost, qualify for the Champions League, as well as either repair the San Siro or build a new stadium for Milan. Once they have created a self sustaining profitable club, then they will look to sell.
